description: ü¶¢Aengus √ìg is god of love, youth, and poetic inspiration in celtic mythology.

historicalAnalysis.academicApproach: Comparative mythology with emphasis on primary sources

methodology.continentalEvidence: Gaulish inscriptions, place names, Roman accounts, archaeology
methodology.insularSources: Medieval Irish and Welsh manuscripts (8th-14th centuries)
methodology.modernScholarship: Contemporary Celtic studies and Indo-European linguistics

historicalContext.geographicOrigin: Ireland (specifically Ulster Cycle and Metrical Dindshenchas)

continentalEvidence.period: Hallstatt & La Tene Iron Age (800-50 BCE)
continentalEvidence.gaulishConnections: Possible connections to youth deities in Gaulish inscriptions, though direct evidence lacks
continentalEvidence.romanInterpretatio: Romans did not significantly document an Aengus equivalent; possibly aligned with Cupido or Eros concepts in interpretatio
continentalEvidence.notes: Primarily an insular Irish deity; scant continental archaeological evidence

primaryTexts: Oidheadh Chloinne Uisneach (Fate of the Children of Uisneach)
insularSources.traditionType: Tuatha D√© Danann mythology; associated with the Otherworld (Brugh na B√≥inne)
insularSources.scholarlyConsensus: Pre-Christian Irish deity preserved through monastic scribal tradition

historicalSources.evidence: Textual preservation of oral traditions in monastic centers
Geographic markers and sacred sites connected to Aengus

archaeologicalContext.artifacts: No direct archaeological associations; part of deity complex predating written record

modernRevival.interpretation: Neo-pagan reconstructionism emphasizes youth, love, and artistic inspiration
modernRevival.accuracy: High respect for medieval sources; some modern interpretations add concepts not present in original texts

family.siblings: Aengus √ìg (brother, god of love), Bodb Derg (brother, later king), Midir, and numerous other children ofthe Dagda
family.children: Ruad√°n (killed in the Battle of Magh Tuireadh), possibly others unnamed
family.consorts: Bres the Beautiful (Fomorian king, later tyrant)
family.parents: The Dagda(father), possibly Boann orDanu(mother - sources vary)

description: Brigid is goddess of fire, poetry, and healing in celtic mythology.

historicalAnalysis.academicApproach: Comparative mythology with emphasis on primary sources

methodology.continentalEvidence: Gaulish inscriptions, place names, Roman accounts, archaeology
methodology.insularSources: Medieval Irish and Welsh manuscripts (8th-14th centuries)
methodology.modernScholarship: Contemporary Celtic studies and Indo-European linguistics

historicalContext.period: Insular Celtic (medieval Irish); possible pre-Christian origins
historicalContext.timeframe: 5th-12th century CE documented; likely pre-Christian worship

continentalEvidence.period: Hallstatt & La Tene Iron Age (800-50 BCE)
continentalEvidence.gaulishConnections: Possible cognates in Celtic languages; no direct Gaulish inscription evidence
continentalEvidence.romanInterpretatio: Romans identified with Minerva (wisdom, craft) and Imbolc associations possibly with Februa
continentalEvidence.notes: Primarily preserved through Irish sources; continental cult practices obscured by Roman conquest

insularSources.traditionType: Tuatha D√© Danann; Festival of Imbolc (Feb 1); Triple goddess form
insularSources.scholarlyConsensus: Pre-Christian fire goddess; later Christianized as Saint Brigid; Christianization represents syncretism rather than complete replacement

historicalSources.source: Thurneysen, Rudolf - Die irische Helden- und K√∂nigssage
historicalSources.evidence: Foundational scholarly analysis of Brigid in Irish mythology

historicalSources.source: O H√≥g√°in, D√°ith√≠ - The Sacred Isle: Belief and Religion in Ireland
historicalSources.evidence: Modern synthesis of pre-Christian Irish religious practices

relatedSites: Kildare (Saint Brigid's shrine; ancient fire temple site)
archaeologicalContext.artifacts: Brigid's wells throughout Ireland; crosses (St. Brigid's crosses); Imbolc fire rituals
archaeologicalContext.periodAssociation: Pre-Christian Iron Age; Christianized medieval period

modernRevival.interpretation: Syncretic figure representing both pre-Christian goddess and Christian saint
modernRevival.accuracy: Scholarly debate: goddess completely replaced vs. saint absorbed goddess functions. Modern paganism recognizes both aspects.

family.consorts: Possibly paired with a great mother goddess figure; some scholars associate him withDanuor similar earth mother figures
family.children: None specifically named, though as a fertility god he may be father to many
family.parents: Unknown - as a primordial nature deity, Cernunnos may predate the Tuatha D√© Danann genealogy

description: ü¶åCernunnos is the horned god of wild nature in celtic mythology.

historicalAnalysis.academicApproach: Comparative mythology with emphasis on primary sources

methodology.continentalEvidence: Gaulish inscriptions, place names, Roman accounts, archaeology
methodology.insularSources: Medieval Irish and Welsh manuscripts (8th-14th centuries)
methodology.modernScholarship: Contemporary Celtic studies and Indo-European linguistics

historicalContext.timeframe: c. 500 BCE - 1 CE; possible continuity into medieval period
historicalContext.geographicOrigin: Gaul/Continental Celtic lands (limited Irish textual evidence)

continentalEvidence.gaulishConnections: Gundestrup Cauldron (1st century BCE) - most significant archaeological evidence of horned deity; epigraphic evidence limited
continentalEvidence.romanInterpretatio: Captured in Lucian's description of Gallic "Ogmios" with chained followers; possibly identified with Dis Pater by Caesar
continentalEvidence.notes: Most securely documented pre-Christian Celtic deity through archaeology rather than texts

primaryTexts: References in medieval Irish literature are scarce and indirect
insularSources.traditionType: Limited direct insular references; primarily reconstructed from continental archaeology
insularSources.scholarlyConsensus: Continental deity whose cult may have extended to Britain/Ireland but documentation is thin

historicalSources.evidence: Silver cauldron with horned figure seated in yogic posture; depiction of Cernunnos
Caesar mentions Gallic veneration of Dis Pater as ancestral deity; possibly references horned god

historicalSources.source: Descriptions of Gallic religion in Roman sources
historicalSources.evidence: Various Roman writers documented Celtic religious practices during conquest

artifacts: Gundestrup Cauldron (1st century BCE silver work)
Horned deity representations in Celtic art
archaeologicalContext.periodAssociation: La Tene Iron Age (500-50 BCE); Roman period (50 BCE-400 CE) continuity uncertain

modernRevival.interpretation: Reconstructionist emphasis on pre-Christian fertility, wildness, and animal mastery
modernRevival.accuracy: Moderate concerns: Medieval Irish texts provide limited direct evidence; most modern understanding relies on archaeological interpretation and Gaulish fragments

family.consorts: Boann (goddess of the River Boyne),the Morrigan(goddess of war),Danu(mother goddess)
family.parents: Son of Elatha, a Fomorian prince (in some accounts)
family.siblings: Ogma (god of eloquence), variousTuatha D√© Dananndeities
family.children: Brigid(goddess of fire and poetry), Aengus √ìg (god of love and youth), Bodb Derg (later king of theTuatha D√© Danann), Cermait (father of smithing gods), Midir the Proud, Aed, and numerous others

historicalAnalysis.academicApproach: Comparative mythology with emphasis on primary sources

methodology.continentalEvidence: Gaulish inscriptions, place names, Roman accounts, archaeology
methodology.insularSources: Medieval Irish and Welsh manuscripts (8th-14th centuries)
methodology.modernScholarship: Contemporary Celtic studies and Indo-European linguistics

historicalContext.timeframe: 8th-12th century CE manuscript preservation; likely pre-Christian origins

continentalEvidence.period: Hallstatt & La Tene Iron Age (800-50 BCE)
continentalEvidence.gaulishConnections: No direct Gaulish inscription evidence; possible cognates in Celtic languages unclear
continentalEvidence.romanInterpretatio: Romans identified some pan-Celtic deity patterns; Dagda's "all-father" role compared to Mars/Jupiter in interpretatio contexts
continentalEvidence.notes: Continental evidence sparse; primarily Irish literary preservation

primaryTexts: Cath Maige Rath (Battle of Mag Rath)
Aided Oenfir A√≠fe (Death of Oenfir A√≠fe)

insularSources.traditionType: Chief of the Tuatha D√© Danann; fertility and sovereignty deity; father figure in mythology
insularSources.scholarlyConsensus: Central pre-Christian Irish deity; name means "Good God"; preserved through monastic tradition

historicalSources.source: Gray, Elizabeth A. - Cath Maige Rath
historicalSources.evidence: Critical edition of Dagda's roles in Irish mythology

historicalSources.source: O Cr√≥in√≠n, D√°ibh√≠ - Early Medieval Ireland 400-1200
historicalSources.evidence: Historical context for mythology preservation during Christianity

relatedSites: Various Tuatha D√© sites in Irish landscape
archaeologicalContext.artifacts: No direct archaeological evidence; mythology reflects pre-Christian sacred geography

modernRevival.interpretation: Emphasis on fertility, abundance, magic, and sovereigndom; central father-god figure
modernRevival.accuracy: High reliance on medieval sources; some modern interpretations add depth not present in fragmentary texts

description: Danu is the primordial mother goddess in celtic mythology.

historicalAnalysis.academicApproach: Comparative mythology with emphasis on primary sources

methodology.continentalEvidence: Gaulish inscriptions, place names, Roman accounts, archaeology
methodology.insularSources: Medieval Irish and Welsh manuscripts (8th-14th centuries)
methodology.modernScholarship: Contemporary Celtic studies and Indo-European linguistics

historicalContext.period: Insular Celtic (medieval Irish); uncertain continental origins
historicalContext.timeframe: 8th-12th century CE preservation; original cult date unknown

continentalEvidence.period: Hallstatt & La Tene Iron Age (800-50 BCE)

continentalEvidence.romanInterpretatio: Romans less documented Danu; possible alignment with Terra Mater (Mother Earth) concepts

insularSources.traditionType: Primordial mother goddess; mother of the Tuatha D√© Danann

archaeologicalContext.artifacts: Primarily literary; geographic markers in place names

modernRevival.interpretation: Mother Goddess; fertility, abundance, magic; central to modern Celtic spirituality
modernRevival.accuracy: Moderate scholarly debate: extent of pre-Christian worship vs. literary creation; modern paganism has emphasized Danu significantly beyond textual evidence

historicalAnalysis.academicApproach: Comparative mythology with emphasis on primary sources

methodology.continentalEvidence: Gaulish inscriptions, place names, Roman accounts, archaeology
methodology.insularSources: Medieval Irish and Welsh manuscripts (8th-14th centuries)

historicalContext.period: Insular Celtic (medieval Irish); possible continental Celtic origins
historicalContext.timeframe: Pre-Christian worship likely; 8th-12th century CE documentation
historicalContext.geographicOrigin: Ireland (Lughnasadh festival widespread in Celtic lands)

continentalEvidence.period: Hallstatt & La Tene Iron Age (800-50 BCE)

continentalEvidence.romanInterpretatio: Romans identified Lugh with Mercury/Hermes (commerce, craft, eloquence); Lugdunum and Lugdunum Batavorum (Leiden) named after Lugus

primaryTexts: Cath Maige Tuired (The Battle of Mag Tuired)

Brief references to Celtic god patterns consistent with Lugh

archaeologicalContext.artifacts: Limited direct artifacts; festival evidence and place name evidence

description: The Greek satirist Lucian (2nd century CE) recorded a striking description of Ogmios as worshipped by the Gauls:

historicalAnalysis.academicApproach: Comparative mythology with emphasis on primary sources

methodology.continentalEvidence: Gaulish inscriptions, place names, Roman accounts, archaeology
methodology.insularSources: Medieval Irish and Welsh manuscripts (8th-14th centuries)
methodology.modernScholarship: Contemporary Celtic studies and Indo-European linguistics

historicalContext.period: Insular Celtic (medieval Irish) with possible continental parallels

continentalEvidence.gaulishConnections: Lucian (2nd century CE) documented Gallic "Ogmios" - explicitly connected to Ogma; possible Gaulish inscription evidence
continentalEvidence.romanInterpretatio: Romans identified Celtic eloquence gods with Mercury/Hermes
continentalEvidence.notes: Strongest continental attestation among major Celtic deities through Lucian's description

primaryTexts: De Gab√°il in t-S√≠da (The Taking of the Fairy Dwelling)
insularSources.traditionType: God of eloquence, writing, strength; inventor of Ogham script (medieval etymology)
insularSources.scholarlyConsensus: Pre-Christian deity; continental-insular continuity demonstrated through Lucian reference

historicalSources.evidence: Explicit documentation of Gallic Ogmios with golden chains of eloquence
Archaeological confirmation of continental worship

historicalSources.source: Jackson, Kenneth - Language and History in Early Britain
historicalSources.evidence: Analysis of Ogham connections and Ogma mythology

archaeologicalContext.periodAssociation: La Tene Iron Age; Roman period continuity; medieval Christian period (Ogham script adaptations)

modernRevival.interpretation: Eloquence, writing, poetry, strength, magic; bardic patron
modernRevival.accuracy: Excellent attestation: both continental (Lucian) and insular evidence; modern interpretations align well with historical sources
